dc46d761-be7c-406e-8503-7bc1eb5d7d4e.content:
What happens when we sleep?

Sleep is key for both mental and physical daily health.

While you sleep, your brain is very active. It is busy creating new pathways in the brain, organising emotions, and sending signals to repair and strengthen the body. As you sleep, your brain moves through sleep cycles, each cycle is just as important as the last, and has a different job.

99e984ec-e213-4164-8b42-0b2902e901d2.content:
How much sleep do we need?

The amount of sleep we need is different for everyone, but the average is 8 hours. Each person is different, but studies show the minimum amount of sleep humans need is 7 hours, but some people can need up to 9. People regularly getting less than 7 hours sleep suffer from sleep deprivation side effects.

Can alcohol harm your quality of sleep?

Watch this video extract featuring Matt Walker, a professor in neuroscience, talking about the effects alcohol has on sleep.

52115aed-24cb-4c67-9dba-3805cc50d702.content:
"Hi my name is Matt Walker, I am a professor of neuroscience at the university of California Berkley, and I am also the author of the book ‘Why We Sleep’.


I’m here to speak about some tips for getting better sleep and also about some of the bad things that happen when you don’t get enough sleep...

14f5fb47-67e3-47fa-8218-b71150890bce.content:
"...So, many of the things that people use to try and help them sleep inadvertently are actually harming and hurting their sleep. 


Two good examples are probably alcohol and marijuana. 


Many people will have a little night cap in the evening because they think that this will help them fall asleep, it’s actually not true...

89d5ba3b-dae5-4671-a74e-0b4616fcab87.content:
"...Alcohol is in a class of drugs that we call the sedatives and sedation is not sleep.


So, what you are doing when you drink in the evening is actually just knocking out your cortex and you are going into this sedation like state, you're not going into natural sleep...

8df121a7-81a5-44aa-831c-09c34d8d37a8.content:
"...There are two other problems with alcohol, unfortunately, and I’m so sorry to be giving you this bad news. 


Firstly, alcohol will actually litter your sleep with many more awakenings throughout the night so when you wake up the next morning you won’t feel restored when you wake up the next morning, you won’t feel refreshed...

10505129-eb20-493c-a6cc-937404f93328.content: "...The problem and the danger is that most people won’t remember waking up in the night after they’ve been drinking, so they don’t realise it was the alcohol disrupting their sleep and they don’t put two and two together...

0f65121e-5f8a-43e0-94a2-5f46ba4be5eb.content:
"...The final thing about alcohol is that it blocks some of your REM sleep, or your dream sleep – your rapid eye movement sleep – and we know that REM sleep is essential for a variety of functions including emotional and mental health. 


And so, alcohol will actually remove that dream sleep, or decrease it significantly, blocking that critical sleep...

f9b3b068-9799-4a05-b02d-4ab47121494b.content:
"...I should also note how essential that REM sleep is. Well, studies done back in the 1980’s - some really quite shocking studies – demonstrated that is you deprive rats of REM sleep they will die almost as quickly as they would from total food deprivation.


That’s how essential that dream sleep is, and it’s that dream sleep you block with alcohol."

Is sleeping really necessary?

The short answer is, yes. Sleeping is as important to mammals as food or water. In fact, lack of sleep can be more harmful than lack of food or water, since the body can fully recover from lack of food or water over time, but the brain can never fully recover from a lack of sleep.

So, how do we get a good night's sleep?

Click through these top tips below to find out how you can improve your sleep.

43027a5c-c98e-4c3a-8b70-10e8398172f6.content: 1. Cut out caffeine, as well as alcohol and marijuana. If you really must drink caffeine, ideally have it in the morning before 9am (assuming a bedtime of 11pm).

a842d095-4eae-4be8-b32a-5b618d56d628.content: 2. Get enough exercise during the day. There is a direct link between deep sleep and exercising, being active promotes healthy sleep.

bbd652c8-f43b-44d9-be69-778fa2b22bd9.content: 3. Make sure your bedroom is free of distractions, noise, and excess light. Make it a dark, peaceful place which helps you relax.

068ed5c7-323e-4903-8933-8e755fa20b12.content: 4. Have a bath before bed. As your body cools off after the bath, this will aid the cooling process which must occur before we can sleep.

055d3a8b-adbe-45ff-8cf9-f31288ac17dd.content: 5. Give yourself enough opportunity to sleep. Don't start preparing for bed too late, assume it may take a while before you actually get to sleep and allow for this.

c275aa5e-b526-4c76-8662-de5bb96d7983.content: 6. Go to sleep and get up at the same time every day, set an alarm to go to bed at first if you are struggling to establish a routine.

1cf065c5-84be-4e12-bca2-a18973ccf9e4.content: 7. Finally, if you do wake in the night and can't go back to sleep, get up and do something relaxing (e.g. reading a book) until you feel sleepy, then return to bed.
